reasoning: The critique targets a supporting premise in Section 3.2: that linear unbounded views are fussy because value-per-resource is (treated as) fat-tailed, making near-best use extremely specific. If that premise failed, the “linear views are necessarily fussy” sub-claim would be weakened, but the overall “no easy eutopia” position has multiple other supports (multiplicative fragility in Section 2; bounded-view arguments in 3.3; and even within 3.2 the scale-requirement part doesn’t rely on fat tails). So centrality is moderate-low. Strength is limited because the critique is mostly a generic parameter-sensitivity point: it doesn’t argue that non-fat-tailed (or sufficiently non-concentrated) value-efficiency distributions are actually plausible, nor that paradigm changes would likely broaden the near-optimal set; and the essay already gestures at uncertainty/robustness (“expected distribution is fat-tailed”). Still, it correctly identifies a hinge where the argument’s robustness could be challenged. Minimal dead weight; it’s a single focused issue and reasonably clear.
title: Shifting technological paradigms could alter the value-efficiency distribution's tail heaviness
